Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Keystone Symposia on "RNA Silencing in Plants" to be held in Keystone, CO from February 17-22, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support attendance by early-career scientists at the Keystone Symposia on RNA Silencing in Plants to be held in Keystone, CO on February 17-22, 2015. The format of the meeting is a combination of talks and posters, which will promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings. There will be ample opportunity for sharing latest research results and for exploring collaborative possibilities.

The field of RNA silencing is fast-moving and many new developments have arisen since the last conference on this topic was held in 2010. This conference will present the latest research in this area through sessions that include: small RNA biogenesis and stability, RNA silencing and germ cell fate, RNA-dependent chromatin modification, transcriptional epigenetic inheritance, chromosomal RNA silencing, RNA signaling, DNA methylation and demethylation, and novel biological functions of noncoding RNA. The conference will be forward-looking with many potential applications in plant breeding and biotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Keystone Symposia meeting on “RNA Silencing in Plants” was held in Keystone, Colorado from February 17-22, 2015.  The meeting organizers were two leading experts in the field, Drs. Robert Martienssen and Craig Pikaard.  The meeting gathered leaders in the field of RNA silencing from around the world with the specific goal of exploring these emerging new functions, and relating them to what is known about existing mechanisms.  This conference explored their implications for real-world problems in plant biotechnology, plant breeding, genetic modification and plant defense for solutions in sustainable agriculture and bioenergy.  The specific aims were:

Aim 1: To understand how noncoding RNAs are generated from specific loci, and are amplified, stabilized or degraded to control their abundance or functions.

Aim 2: To understand how noncoding RNAs target specific genomic loci and specify regions of chromatin modification.

Aim 3: To understand the relative roles of small RNAs and the Argonaute proteins that bind the small RNAs in RNA-mediated silencing processes.

Aim 4: To explore new biological functions of noncoding RNAs and methods that are providing new insights.

Aim 5: To provide a forum for junior faculty members, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students to share their work with other experts and trainees interested in RNA silencing in plants.

     The program developed by Drs. Martienssen and Pikaard was designed to combine classical mechanisms of RNA silencing with the most recently discovered biological consequences of these same mechanisms for gene regulation, transposon and virus control, and cell fate specification.  Plenary sessions addressed key challenges in the field and stimulated new thinking especially in the biological significance of the mechanisms that have been uncovered in recent years.  The latest advances in our understanding of the roles for RNA silencing in cells, the molecular mechanisms that underlie these processes, as well as their applications, were presented by leading scientists in the field during this meeting.    

     This meeting brought together an international community of researchers, scholars, and graduate and postdoctoral trainees to share new insights and discoveries focused on the roles of multiple classes of long and short noncoding RNAs in transposon taming, genome organization and stability, DNA and histone modifications, development and epigenetic inheritance.  Collectively, the symposium explored the surprising ways in which RNAs, rather than proteins, mediate critical biological regulatory mechanisms, which is revolutionizing our thinking of how an organism’s genotype can specify alternative phenotypes.
